issues.description: Parameter type of raisePressure is inconsistent between the UML in the problem statement and the implemented solution/remarks. The UML (problem_statement.md) declares raisePressure(pressure: double): void, but the problem remarks text refers to raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) and the solution implementation (Pneumatic interface and its overrides) uses an int parameter. This mismatch will confuse students which parameter type to use and will cause signature/test mismatches (students following the UML will implement raisePressure(double) while the reference solution and tests expect int, or vice versa).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the parameter type across all artifacts. Either: (A) Change the UML and problem text to declare raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) so it matches the solution and remarks; or (B) Preferably (to match the UML), update the solution and the remark text to use double: change the Pneumatic interface signature to void raisePressure(double pressureIncrease) and update the overriding methods in LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster accordingly, and correct the remark to mention raisePressure(double). Ensure tests and templates are updated to expect the chosen type.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(pressure: double) (problem_statement.md lines 16-19), but elsewhere in the same problem text the method is referenced as raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) (problem_statement.md lines 71-72). The solution implementation declares the interface method as void raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java lines 3-7). This mismatch (parameter name and — importantly — parameter type) between the UML in the problem statement and the solution creates a mapping conflict: a student following the UML would implement raisePressure(double pressure) while the provided solution/tests expect raisePressure(int pressureIncrease). The inconsistency is likely unintentional and can cause compilation/test failures or extra cognitive load when students try to match the UML to the template/solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method signature for raisePressure across artifacts. Prefer updating the UML in problem_statement.md to match the implemented solution and remarks: change the UML declaration to raisePressure(pressureIncrease: int) (i.e., void raisePressure(int pressureIncrease)). Ensure the template Pneumatic.java (starter code) and any textual references use the same signature so students have a single, consistent target.
